MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

HERSEY, MI 49639-9756
License Status: Regular

Capacity: 20

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Multiple youth in the facility have been cheeking medication. The
youth have been combining medication, crushing them, and giving
the medication to other youth to take as well as snorting the
medications themselves.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant became aware of the allegations while
completing a separate special investigation at the facility (SI
2025SIC0000541).
Youth A was interviewed via teams on 4/17/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported she takes
medications at the facility including Trazadone, Lexapro, and
Guanfacine. Youth A reported medications are passed by staff
who are medication trained. Youth A reported when she takes her
medications, she is provided with her medications and a cup of
water. Youth A reported after she takes her medications and
drinks the water, staff check in her mouth and have her move her
tongue around, staff have her pull her cheeks out with her finger,
and blow to show the medication is no longer in her mouth. Youth
A reported she has cheeked medications at the facility. Youth A
reported all staff look in her mouth after she takes her medications
however some staff are “better at looking” such as Staff 1. Youth
A reported some staff even use a flashlight to look in youth’s
mouths to ensure youth are not cheeking medications. Youth A
reported there is not any specific staff that she knows she can
cheek medications with, it is more of just if she can hide her
medication well enough for the staff not to see the medication in
her mouth. Youth A reported she cheeks her medications
because she feels the medications are not working for her. Youth
A reported sometimes she will keep her medications and put them
in a bag and crush them up along with Youth B’s medications.
Youth A reported she and Youth B sometimes snort the
medication to get high. Youth A reported this started when she
first arrived at the facility and stopped for a while, however
recently she and Youth B began combining their medications and
crushing the medications to snort it. Youth A reported she
provided a male youth at the facility her Trazadone (this is being
addressed in special investigation 2025SIC0000541). Youth A
2

reported she gave the male youth the medication in school
however did not recall the day. Youth A reported another male
youth took the bag of medication and dumped it out. Youth A
reported no staff at the facility or school knew about the
medications being passed or snorted. Youth A reported she was
“high” the day she gave the medications to the male youth and did
not recall details. Youth A reported she does not know any other
youth cheeking or passing medications at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported she is prescribed to take medications at the facility.
Youth B reported staff who are trained to pass medications give
her the prescribed medications in a cup, Youth B takes the
medications, drinks a cup of water, and the staff checks her mouth
to make sure the medication was taken by having her move her
tongue around while the staff looks in her mouth. Youth B
reported she has cheeked medication previously at the facility as
well as she reported Youth A has. Youth B reported last week, she
had a bag of crushed medications in her pocket, and she did not
realize she dropped the bag and Therapist found it. Youth B
reported Youth A told her she dropped it and Youth A saw
Therapist pick up the bag. Youth B reported the crushed
medications were a mixture of pills including Adderall, pain
medications, Melatonin, Trazadone, and other medications she
did not recall. Youth B reported she and Youth A had “stocked
up” medications and crushed the medications. Youth B reported
the crushed medications were in a diamond art bag. Youth B
reported she had given some of the crushed medications to Youth
C “a while ago”. Youth B reported she did not “snort” the
medications often, she and Youth A would hold medications that
they were able to cheek until they had “enough” to crush and
snort. Youth B reported all staff check youth’s mouths when youth
take medications, it just depends how good she or other youth are
at cheeking as to if they can get away with it. Youth B reported no
staff at the facility knew about the medications being crushed
and/or cheeked until Therapist found the crushed medications in
the bag she dropped. Youth B reported she has only given
crushed medications to Youth A and Youth C at the facility. Youth
B reported she is not aware of any other specific youth cheeking
medication at the facility however reported sometimes youth,
unwilling to name who, bring medication back from home visits.
Youth B reported Youth A gave crushed medications to one of the
male youth at the facility, however another male youth took the
pills away from the youth. Youth B reported she did not know the
specifics regarding this incident as she did not see it however was
3

told by Youth A (this is being addressed in Special Investigation
2025SIC0000541).
Youth C was interviewed via telephone on 4/18/2025 in
collaboration with Courtesy MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported
she attended school with the male youth when she was placed at
the facility. Youth C reported she began taking medications one
week prior to her leaving the facility. Youth C reported at
medication time; youth are provided their medication one at a time
by staff who are trained to pass medications. The staff would
provide her medications and a cup of water, she would take the
medication, drink the water, and the staff would check in her
mouth. Youth C reported the staff would have her stick her
tongue out and move her tongue around in her mouth to make
sure she was not cheeking her medications. Youth C reported
she never cheeked her medication at the facility and always took
her medication as staff would watch her. Youth C reported youth
at the facility have cheeked medication, however she did not know
how as the staff would watch the youth take the medication and
check their mouths. Youth C reported Youth A and Youth B have
cheeked their medications. Youth C reported Youth A and Youth
B would crush up their medications and snort them. Youth C
reported she had witnessed Youth A and Youth B have a bag with
crushed up medications. Youth C reported Youth A and Youth B
would snort the medication in their bedroom or bathroom so staff
would not see. Youth C reported Youth A nor Youth B never
appeared intoxication or “high” after snorting the medications.
Youth C reported there was no specific staff that Youth A and
Youth B could get away with cheeking the medications during
medication pass time. Youth C reported she snorted medication
one time at the facility in the bathroom however it did not get her
high or have any impact on her. Youth C reported she did not
remember what medications she snorted, who gave them to her,
when she snorted the medications, or what staff were working.
Youth C reported Youth A and Youth B did not snort medications
often at the facility. Youth C reported the youth in her house
never passed medication to the male youth on campus that she
was aware of.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Therapist
reported she was in the school hallway talking to Youth A when
Staff 3 walked up to her and gave her a bag with white substance
in it after Youth B ran past her in the hallway. Therapist believed
this occurred on Monday. Therapist reported she went to the
house later that day and Youth B told her the bag with the white
4

substance belonged to her. Therapist reported an incident report
was written regarding the incident. Therapist reported she
provided the bag with white substance to nursing department this
morning. Therapist reported Youth B asked her if she was going
to report the incident and Therapist informed Youth B she was.
Therapist reported she did not have any specific information as to
what the white substance was or where Youth B got it from.
Therapist reported she was aware Youth A attempted to cheek
medication last night as she was provided the incident report.
Therapist reported Youth A told her the bag with the white
substance belonged to Youth B. Therapist reported the bag was a
diamond art bag that the white substance was in.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1
reported she is trained to pass medications at the facility and
passed medications last night and frequently passes medications
at the facility. Staff 1 reported she provided Youth A her
medications and Youth A would not lift up her tongue last night for
Staff 1 to check to ensure she had taken the medications. Staff 1
reported Youth A eventually lifted her tongue up at which time
Staff 1 saw Youth A had her pills still in her mouth. Staff 1
reported she had Youth A spit the medications out into the
medication cup. Staff 1 reported this was the first time that she
was aware of Youth A cheeking her medications. Staff 1 reported
she asked Youth A why she was not taking her medications and
Youth A told her the medications give her nightmares. Staff 1
talked to Youth A about refusing medications and addressing her
concerns with medical staff verses cheeking her medications.
Staff 1 reported she wrote an incident report regarding the
situation. Staff 1 reported no other youth that she was aware of
have been cheeking medication in the house. Staff 1 reported the
process for passing medications to youth includes giving the youth
the medications in a cup with a separate cup of water. The youth
take the medication and then drink the cup of water. Staff have
youth open their mouths and move their tongue around and have
the youth use their fingers to pull each side of their cheeks out so
the staff can look thoroughly in the youth’s mouth to ensure the
medication was taken. Staff 1 reported staff also have youth blow
out as hard as they can to show there is nothing in their mouths.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/29/2025. Staff 2 reported she is trained to pass medications at
the facility. Staff 2 reported medications are passed by staff
logging into the MAR on the computer to match the youth with the
prescribed medications for the medication pass time. Staff 2
5

reported the medications are placed in a cup and she labels the
cup with the youth’s initials. The youth is called to come up to
take the medication. Staff 2 reported the youth is given their
medications in the cup however if a youth has thrown medications
prior then she will pour the medications into the youth’s mouth.
The youth is given a cup of water to drink. Staff 2 reported she
checks the youth’s mouth after the youth drinks the water to
ensure the medications were taken and not still in the youth’s
mouth by having the youth use their finger to move their checks
out to the side and has the youth lift their tongue around while she
looks in the youth’s mouth. Staff 2 reported she then has youth
cough or blow to make sure the medication is not cheeked or
stuck in the youth’s throat. Staff 2 reported she is not aware of
any youth recently and/or currently cheeking medications at the
facility. Staff 2 reported all staff follow the same medication
passing process and she has never witnessed any staff fail to
check youth’s mouths for cheeking medication. Staff 2 reported
medication passing and process is a commonly discussed topic at
staff meetings at the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via teams meeting on 5/8/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she was in
the activity therapy center and was walking behind Youth A and
Youth B. Staff 3 reported she saw a bag on the ground and
picked it up and gave the bag to Therapist. Staff 3 reported she
did not see the bag fall out of anyone’s pocket; she just saw the
bag laying on the ground. Staff 3 reported she did not know for
sure what was in the bag however she believed it to be crushed
medication. Staff 3 reported Youth A later told her she thought the
bag belonged to Youth B. Staff 3 reported she is not trained to
pass medications to youth at the facility. Staff 3 reported she is
not aware of any youth at the facility cheeking medications.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Standards for Drug Administration: All
medications dispensed orally need to be followed by youth
drinking an entire 4 ounce glass of water in front of staff as
the witness. Staff are to view the inside of the youth’s mouth
after they drink 4 ounces of water. This includes the youth
lifting their tongue to the roof of their mouth, moving their
tongue to the right side of their mouth and then moving their
tongue to the left side of their mouth. Youth are then to pull
out each side of their cheeks in order for staff to view the
inside of their cheeks to ensure there is no medication being
stored or “cheeked.” Whenever a youth has cheeked a
6

medication, please write a Medication Incident Report and
notify the Residential Treatment Supervisor and the Medical
Staff.
• Eagle Village Incident Reported dated 4/9/2025 for Youth A:
Youth A attempted to cheek her medication to avoid taking
them. Youth A hid both of her bedtime medications
(Melatonin and Trazodone) under her tongue and refused to
lift her tongue up during med checks for Staff 1. All youth
are very aware that in medication checks their mouths need
to be open, they need to have their tongue go up down,
swipe both cheeks, and then blow air on their finger so that
staff can ensure they aren't cheeking meds. Staff 1 got Youth
A to spit her meds out into her medication cup.
• Eagle Village Incident Report dated 4/7/2025 for Youth B:
Therapist was in the hallway talking to a youth when Youth
B ran by. Staff 2 was close behind Youth B and handed
therapist a small plastic bag with a crushed powder inside
and stated it fell as Youth B and a peer ran by. Therapist
went to the house and Youth B admitted to Therapist the
medications were hers.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3’s personnel files: Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Staff 3 had no discipline. Staff 1 and Staff 2 received
medication training on 8/28/2024. Staff 3 does not pass
medications at the facility and is not medication trained.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Based on interviews with staff
and youth, the facility is following their internal administrating
medication policy and staff are checking youth’s mouths. In
addition, per incident reports, staff have caught youth cheeking
medication.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility continues to educate and train staff regarding
ensuring thorough checks of youth’s mouths after a youth
has taken medication including checking with a flashlight as
youth have indicated staff check however it depends on
how well the youth can hide the medication in their mouth.
• The facility complete thorough checks of youth returning
from home passes to ensure youth are not bringing
medications into the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
5/28/2025
Jennifer Pastorick Date
Licensing Consultant
